title: Soapstone Prairie offers remote, beautiful experience
text:
Soapstone Prairie offers remote, beautiful experience Stephen Meyers , stephenmeyers@coloradoan.com 8:27 a.m. MDT October 14, 2015 Buy Photo Soapstone Prairie Natural Area features many native grasses and flowers. (Photo: Stephen Meyers/The Coloradoan) Buy Photo 7 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
SOAPSTONE PRAIRIE - The wind pounds my face and nearly knocks me off my bike as I pedal toward Wyoming. 
A slight breeze in Fort Collins is a real blow up here on the northern prairie of Colorado (you can blame the Cowboy State). But what a pretty prairie it is out here at Soapstone Prairie Natural Area. 
The rolling fields of blonde sideoats grama wave in a golden shimmer as the sun descends on this warm mid-October Monday. Three-leaf sumac hangs on to its fall color, displaying vibrant, campfire-like shades of orange and red. 
The 11.7-mile Cheyenne Ridge Trail takes me through brown buffalo grass, climbing, weaving and descending in and out of dry washes and across narrow rock outcroppings and gorgeous redrock ridges. 
Like Pawnee National Grasslands, you won’t be blown away by the scenery from the parking lot, but the deeper you go into this 28-square-mile natural area, the more beauty you’ll find. 
You’ve probably heard about Soapstone Prairie thanks to a pair of furry animals that call, or soon will call, the 18,728 acres near the Wyoming border home. 
In September 2014, 42 endangered black-footed ferrets were released onto the prairie, and earlier this month, 17 more of the cute critters joined their comrades at Soapstone. 
As cool as that is, the natural area’s big headline animal is the 10 bison that, come Nov. 1, will roam 800 acres of this shortgrass prairie. The future - and at one time past - home of the bison is visible from Soapstone’s entrance road and the recently realigned Cheyenne Rim Trail. 
I think of the bison during my ride on the singletrack trail, imagining the 30 million 1,500-pound mammals that used to freely roam North America’s plains. What a powerful, majestic animal. 
I wouldn’t want to come up close to one. 
Last month, the first 3 miles of the Cheyenne Ridge Trail were rerouted to avoid any bison-biker-hiker-horseback rider conflicts. 
Whew. Buy Photo 
Soapstone Prairie Natural Area, north of Fort Collins, offers great mountain biking on several miles of trails. (Photo: Stephen Meyers/The Coloradoan) 
Coming around a bend, I see a herd of pronghorn antelope 50 yards away, grazing on a hill. The squeaks of my brakes spooked the sleek, fast animals, and after a short stare down, they gallop away. 
My destination on this mountain bike ride is adjoining Red Mountain Open Space’s Big Hole, a striking geological feature. You’re riding along through the grassland, when, bam, you arrive to a scene of gorgeous redrock and a dry wash floor featuring millions of years worth of uplift, folding and erosion. 
By this time, the wind and the trail’s rolling hills leave me zapped, even though I want to explore more. 
The opportunity is there for an epic day of mountain bike riding. 
The Cheyenne Rim Trail continues into Red Mountain Open Space, where you can ride all the way into Wyoming’s Big Hole Open Space. Cheyenne Rim also connects with the Canyon Trail, which takes you into the eastern portion of Soapstone Prairie. 
Perhaps the best part? 
The lack of people. 
If you’re into finding solitude and a remote experience, Soapstone Prairie is your place. I encounter one person - a horseback rider - during my ride. 
Just remember, this is the unforgiving plains, where storms can arrive with no notice, temperatures can greatly and quickly fluctuate and you’re more than an hour away from emergency services. The conditions are so harsh, the natural area is closed December through February. 
So go now to experience the most natural of Fort Collins' natural areas. 
Soapstone Prairie Natural Area 
Where: 25 miles north of Fort Collins. From Fort Collins, take Colorado Highway 1/Terry Lake Road to County Road 15 north (toward Waverly). From County Road 15, turn north onto Rawhide Flats Road and continue north to the entrance station. 
Hours : Dawn to dusk, March 1 to Dec. 1. Soapstone Prairie is closed in December, January and February. 
Pets: Not allowed 
Trails 
South trailhead 
Open to horseback riding, cycling and hiking. All trailheads have a picnic shelter, vault toilet, information kiosk and parking. 
Cheyenne Rim Trail: 11.7 miles with connection to Canyon Trail and Red Mountain Open Space. 
Pronghorn Loop: 7.5 mile loop with connection to Plover Trail and Sand Wash Trail 
Plover Trail : 7 miles, closed April 1- July 15 for grassland birds, connects to Pronghorn Loop and Sandwash Trail 
North trailhead 
Open to cycling and hiking, unless where noted. Horses are not allowed. 
Lindenmeier Overlook : 1/4 mile paved trail to pavilion with interpretive signs and seating 
Mahogany Trail : 5 mile trail with connection to Canyon Trail and Pronghorn Loop 
Towhee Trail: 3-mile loop for hiking only with connection to Mahogany Trail and Canyon Trail 
Canyon Trail: 5 mile trail on north edge of property with connection to Plover Trail and Red Mountain Open Space 
Sand Wash Trail: 1.5 miles connects Canyon Trail and Pronghorn Loop 
Information: www.fcgov.com/naturalareas/finder/soapstone 
Soapstone Prairie Natural Area is a great horseback riding destination north of Fort Collins. (Photo: Stephen Meyers/The Coloradoan)
